sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a puzzle game where you try and find the location of mines floating in an ocean using only your brain and a little bit of luck.

You start the game with a grid of blank squares - you have no idea what is in them. Clicking on a square shows you what is under it, either empty ocean or a mine. If you find a mine bad things happen and the game is over. To make the game longer and more fun, if you find an empty piece of ocean a number is printed there telling you how many mines are in the adjacent squares (or no number if there are no nearby mines). Once you find a few clear squares you can start to deduce which squares have mines in them and which don't. You win the game once you have revealed all the un-mined squares and marked where all the mines are.

figure.title: The games. As you start it, while playing, when you lose, and when you win.

sect1.para: To mark a square as having a mine you right-click on it and a flag is placed there. If you click on a square with a number and you have placed precisely that number of flags on adjacent squares then the remaining squares are revealed. If you didn't mark the mines correctly then an explosion will occur and once-again the game is over. Squares with no adjacent mines (i.e. blank squares) have the adjacent squares automatically cleared.

Also, you are being timed. You have to work quickly - and correctly. Once you have found all the mines and revealed all the un-mined squares the timer is stopped. The shorter the time you take, the better.
The time you have taken is displayed on the bottom right of the window. Beside it on the left is a count of the number of mines you have cleared and the total number hidden on the board.

figure.title: There is also a big yellow face. Don't be frightened - it's harmless.

sect1.title: The Details
sect1.para: The intro is short, so here are the gory details.

sect2.title: The Goal
sect2.para: Starting from an ocean of squares with unknown contents you must mark all the squares with mines and reveal all the clear squares. Actually you don't have to mark the squares with mines, but it is a lot easier if you do. Once you have cleared all the un-mined squares, any remaining mined squares will be marked for you.

If you left click on a mine, or auto-clear a square with a mine in it you lose. To help prevent accidents, you aren't allowed to auto-clear around a square unless the number of marked mines equals the number given in the square.

sect2.title: Using the Mouse

row.entry: Left click on an un-revealed square.
Reveals that square for better or for worse.
Left click in a revealed square.
Reveals the unmarked squares around the square, but only if enough squares have been marked to match the number in the revealed square.
Right click on an un-revealed square.
Marks the square as a mine. If it is already marked, it will clear it.

sect2.tip: If you are used to the more traditional mouse controls don't worry; they still work.

sect2.title: Game Size and Difficulty
sect2.para: By choosing SettingsPreferences from the menu you can change the size of the games. Larger sizes obviously take longer and require more concentration. Smaller games are more frantic. We provide Small, Medium, Large and Custom sizes.

On the right hand side of the dialog there are three parameters for controlling the custom size. Horizontal and Vertical are the width and height of the desired custom grid in squares. The number of mines is - obviously - the number of mines you need to find. If this number is set too high or too low then the game becomes very easy. The number of mines is limited to slightly less than the total number of squares.

sect2.title: "I'm not sure" Flags
sect2.para: There is one other check-box in the properties dialog entitled Use "I'm not sure" flags. If you enable this then when right-clicking on a square it cycles between the normal flags used to mark the square as mined, a flag with a question mark on it and no flag. This new flag is to help you with your reasoning, to mark mines you think might be a mine. These flags have no effect on the game; you still have to use the appropriate number of red marker flags to be able to clear around a numbered square.

figure.title: The sequence of flags when "I'm not sure" flags are enabled.

sect2.title: Hints
sect2.para: If you get stuck - it is reasonably common to end up with two options that you can't logically resolve - then you can either guess, or ask for a hint. When you choose Hint from the Game menu then a single square will be revealed (plus surrounding squares if it is blank). The choice of square is not deterministic, but should be helpful. There is 10 second penalty added to your time whenever you use a hint.

sect2.title: High Scores
sect2.para: If your score is in the top ten then, when the game is over, you will be shown the list of top scores and have an opportunity to change the name you use in the list. You can also review the scores later by choosing Scores from the Game menu. The drop-down menu at the top of the dialog lets you look at other categories.
sect2.tip: The high score for the custom size is usually meaningless. Any other player can make the game size smaller and get a better time. If you only ever play one custom size then it will tell you how well you are doing. This is the reason it is still recorded.

sect2.title: Window Size
sect2.para: Resizing the window makes the squares bigger or smaller to suit. If you want to make maximum use of the screen then the Fullscreen option under the Settings menu will do what you want. You can also use F11 key to toggle full-screen mode.

sect2.title: The Basics
sect2.para: There are a few basic situations which should be incredibly obvious, but if you're struggling with how to play this game, they should be useful. The first is the case where you have an isolated uncovered square and every square around it reads 1. That uncovered square is a mine.

The next simplest case is where you have two uncovered squares adjacent to each other and both squares on one side are marked with a 2. If they have no other uncleared neighbours, then both squares are mines.
Finally, when there are three uncovered squares in a row and the clear square beside the middle one is a 3 (once again this square should have no other neighbours) then all three are mines.
